texts.shortText: Head and body form a flattened disc with a stiff, pointed snout supported by a stout cartilage and wide, wing-like pectoral fins. Tail narrow with two small rounded dorsal fins near tip. Single row of thorn-like structures along mid-dorsal line of snout, disc and tail. Colour dorsally light brown with numerous small black spots and a larger eye-spot at base of each pectoral fin. Underside white with small mouth and short gill slits.
Up to 68 cm disc width and a mass of about 1.4 kg, females growing larger than males.

Global: Western Sahara down west coast of Africa to South Africa, possibly also Mozambique, Mauritius and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Namibia to East London.

Occurs on sand from the surf zone to a depth of 690 m. Generally found singly lying on, or shallowly covered by, sand where well camouflaged. Males reach sexual maturity at about 56–68 cm total length and females at 55–71 cm.
Feeds mainly on bony fish, as well as on crustaceans and squid.

Oviparous, egg cases laid two at a time. The tough, brown, rectangular cases with a pointed horn at each corner and are about 8 cm long (excluding horns). Egg cases lie freely on the substratum during development, which takes several months. Size at hatching about 16 cm total length.
The Spearnosed skate Rostroraja alba has a similar body shape and snout, but is usually grey in colour, sometimes with white spots and has three (not one) rows of large thorns along the tail.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 262).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 81).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 587).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 126).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 18).
